Award.AwardTitle: Evolution Of Behavioral Immune Responses In Fruit Flies: Tradeoffs, Mechanisms, And Genetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Because immune defenses against parasites are costly, hosts are expected to balance the use of different defense mechanisms and to forego immunity when they do not need it. However, experimental evidence for trade-offs between alternative defense mechanisms is scarce. The ideal system to test for immune response tradeoffs would be a group of closely related host species that face similar parasites in the wild, and that employ multiple kinds of defenses. The investigators will use fruit flies of the melanogaster species group of the genus Drosophila, along with their shared endoparasitoid wasps from the family Figitidae, to test the hypothesis that cellular and behavioral immune defenses trade off with each other on a macro-evolutionary scale. The investigators will take advantage of the fact that D. melanogaster is a genetic model system to test the suspected roles of sight and brain neuropeptide F signaling in fly self-medication responses against wasp parasites. The investigators will also take a combined RNA-seq and association mapping approach to uncover further brain genes required for initiating behavioral defenses. This project will result in the identification of evolutionary trade-offs between different immune mechanisms as well as the mechanistic and genetic underpinnings of behavioral immune responses.

Broader impacts of the project include the maintenance and distribution of parasitic wasp strains for the scientific community and the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students in aspects of behavior, cellular biology, and genetics. The investigators will also collaborate with public high school teachers to develop classroom projects focused on hands-on, student-centered, and inquiry-based learning approaches using the fly-wasp immunological interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parasites are common in nature and constantly reduce the fitness of their hosts – thus, hosts have evolved mechanisms to defend themselves against parasites including cellular, molecular, and behavioral defenses. This project was focused on behavioral defense mechanisms because very little is known about the ultimate and proximate mechanisms behind behavioral defenses, e.g. how important they are relative to other types of defense, and how hosts actually use their brains to limit parasitism.  We used fruit flies in the genus Drosophila, along with the wasp parasites that infect Drosophila in nature and eat their hosts form the inside out, as our model host-parasite system.

Aim 1 of the project was designed to test whether there is a relationship between the strength of the cellular encapsulation response that Drosophila species mount against wasp eggs in their body cavities, and any reduction in egglaying the flies undergo in response to forced cohabitation with adult wasps (a behavioral adaptation to protect their offspring). Although we found variation in both traits across Drosophila species, independent contrast analyses revealed little evidence of a negative correlation, or tradeoff, between these two components of fly defense.  It may be that the induced behavioral defense is not costly, or that each type of defense is necessary under different conditions. We also made progress on three other “alternative” defense responses that flies employ against parasitic wasps, which will allow us to pursue further comparative studies across Drosophila species in the future.  For example, we found that found that flies increase their meiotic recombination rate following infection by bacteria or parasitic wasps.  This causes fly offspring to be more genetically variable than otherwise, potentially making it harder for parasites to specialize on particular host genotypes. We also found that fly larvae burrow underground when wasps begin infecting nearby fly larvae, and we are designing experiments to test whether the flies recognize the presence of the wasps directly (and if so, how), or whether infected flies emit a danger signal to other flies.

Aim 2 of the project was designed to test whether flies use vision and/or olfaction to sense the presence of wasp parasites in their environment. We found that both sensory modalities are required. We then delved deeper into how flies see wasps by assaying mutant flies that lack the three main components of vision: the ability to detect color, the ability to detect motion, and the ability to detect pattern.  Flies lacking color vision and the ability to detect pattern failed to recognize wasps, while flies that fail to detect motion responded to wasps normally.  We are also using video playback of wasps to stimulate the fly response, which will allow us to alter the images in the videos and further flesh out what defines the flies' wasp search image. 

In Aim 3 of the project we used genetic association studies and transcriptome sequencing to identify novel genes and pathways involved in fly behavioral defenses. For example, we undertook an association study designed to identify genetic variation associated with one kind of behavioral defense – reduced egglaying in the presence of wasps. Dozens of significant associations were found, and we are now testing mutant strains for the candidate genes to confirm their role in the oviposition reduction behavior. So far, two of the candidate genes have been validated and we are in the process of testing ten more, some of which were also identified as being up-regulated in fly brains following exposure to wasp parasites. We have devised new cell and molecular biology experiments for future work to elucidate exactly how our newly identified genes control fly defense behaviors.

With respect to broader impacts, in order to engage younger students in scientific research, I had the lab sections of my Evolutionary Biology classes run class-wide artificial selection and genetic association study experiments on fly behaviors. A handful of students continued to work with me after the class ended to further characterize candidate genes from the different experiments. I also continued a collaboration with a local high school science teacher to develop teaching modules using fruit flies that meet the federal “next generation” teaching standards. We will publish a description of our novel teaching modules in a pedagogy journal so that teachers across the country can adopt them as they transition to the new federal standards.  I also took part in “science days” and lab tours for local elementary school students as part of the Reed College Science Outreach Program and the University of Arizona Insect Discovery Program, and ran booths on host-parasite interactions at the Arizona Insect Festival, which is attended by thousands of people.
